subject: Re: junit tests and functional/ integration tests
msgSnippet: Hi Bill We have junit tests and java property files. They run in a specific sequence and get their data from the property files. That is fine for completed
messageBody:
Hi Bill

We have junit tests and java property files. They run in a specific
sequence and get their data from the property files. That is fine for
completed tests.
But we need something like a workflow in the tests; eg. test1 creates
something in the database and test x uses the same data to verify
some additional testcases.
We started to examine jxunit, unfortunately it is not that well
documented..

cheers

erik

--- In junit@y..., "Bill Laird" <wlaird@w...> wrote:
> Hi Erik - I'm not quite sure what you are trying to say. Unit tests
in the classic sense are mutually exclusive from functional tests.
There may be some overlap in coverage, but there is no union of test
cases.
>
> Is what you are trying to say is that you want to use Junit as a
framework and harness for black box functional testing of Java API's?
>
>
> Cheers,
> Bill
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: erikstunkat
> To: junit@y...
> Sent: Wednesday, April 17, 2002 4:26 AM
> Subject: [junit] junit tests and functional/ integration tests
>
>
> Hi,
> I know that unit tests should run on their own and every test
should
> be executable of its own - but..
> we want to use unit tests for a QA related functional framework
and
> we yet defined some tasks with ant to run tests in a specific
order.
> My question: is there any extension for junit to define
properties
> for tests in a more straightforward way then java properties
files
> (xml?) and to combine several unit tests with global attributes
and
> properties?
>
> thanks in advance!
>
> erik stunkat
